It would be hard to determine who is more successful due to the amount of interpretations that need to be produced. When Mark is in one area and Dan in another during a certain time of day and they switch spots on a different day, at the same time, the conditions could vary. The weather could effect the production of fish for each, as well as the attention and equipment involved. Seeing as it is most likely that conditions will vary for each time and day, data would need to be regularly conducted. It would take more than a few weeks to determine the exactness of who is better at fishing because of the difference in daily attributes. The amount of equipment and effectivness would be a huge factor as well. Unless they are both using the same fishing gear, it will be hard to determine who is better at fishing based solely on their experience. They could go back to the same fishing area during the same time the next year and find that they are worse off than they were the year before. Then, Mark might find that he is catching more fish than Dan, simply because Mark has better equipment, or the current that day in the area he was fishing was more suitable for a fisherman or vice versa.

In order to accurately figure out if this company is accepting more displays than rejecting them, a judgement call as well as technical properties must be in place. There must be a basis of what a "good" screen display looks like in the eyes of the person examining it and what would be considered a "bad" screen display. Whether the screen is manually fixable could be another factor the interpret when figuring out which are bad and which are good for this company and supplyer. Whether the company wants to continue to order from a supplier that gives more than 5% bad displays or find another supplier, or lower the standards in which they consider to be bad and good would be a factor as well. Would the company profit more from simply selling the bad displays for a lower price, or would they benefit from returning the whole thing with exactly 5% bad, and neglect the 95% that were good and let them go to waste. Are damaged boxes on the outside considered "bad" or would the display itself having a crack or scratch be considered "bad?" There are many factors to put into consideration before diving into this problem. Is 5% a probable and beneficial percentage and limit to the companies standards, or would they benefit from having a higher number of defects in order to accept or reject the order?

You want to find the probability that in the population of 150 screens, less than 5% of those are bad. There are two possible outcomes: bad or not bad.     / 1. Take a sample of the screens (for example, 40)  / 2. Count how many of those are bad.  / 3. divide the found number by the n (40) --> this is the sample probability.  / 4. if this number is smaller than 0.05, then the order should be accepted
